Topic.Title: "Microsoft Eyes 3 New Surface Tablet Servings for 2013"

Topic.Title: Digitimes: Tegra 4 stands good chance of becoming a new platform for Win RT

Message.Msg: I had some extra time and so I spent an hour this weekend getting familiar with the Surface at a Microsoft Kiosk ( I already own an iPad) My take away is that sales will pick up in 2013, the device is actually very sweet. Physically it feels well engineered and made of high quality material, the keyboard snaps into place effortlessly using magnets as does the power cable. The user experience is functionaly rich and very smooth and the inclusion of Office Suite is very desirable. Many features over the iPad including a native HDMI out ( not a #$%$ adapter) and a USB port you can use for a mouse, local storage etc. The fact that the iPhone 5 is seeing less sales that anticpated shows Apple is vunerable and folks are not buying Apple blindly as they once were. Still, Microsoft faces an uphill battle to garnish mind share, but the Surface is worthy of consideration and I suspect the Microsoft "fly wheel" will gain some momentum thru 2013. For one thing, the guys at the Kiosk need to be more direct about competitive against iPad. I saw a lot of lookers but not many buyers. They need to turn those lookers into Surface adopters. Apple can afford to Mr. and Mrs nice guy in retail because demand exists but if Microsoft wants to sell some Surfaces they need to step it up and go right after Apple and not be shy about it. Tegra 4 will be a nice addition , and I can see Microsoft adding XBOX type controllers via USB to lure PC gamers. The Tablet wars are not over, its only begining

Message.Msg: Seems the market isn't done telling Nvidia how silly that project name like a condom is, hmm? A Tegra phone in one pocket, a SHIELD toy in the other and a tegra tablet in hand is just what every Nvidia fan needs to go with those empty back pockets where a fat wallet once lived until that Nvidia stock purchase. Here's to many enjoyable hours of playing with your portable pocket SHIELD toy Nvdia fans. lol imho

LIke you, I like the company, and I think it has a future. Tegra 4 was just announced, and I expect we'll see some product announcements in the lead up to the MWC next month. Earnings probably won't be stellar, but should meet estimates at least. But, I'm getting beat up pretty bad here on this recent decline. I'm sitting on some serious losses after CES, and I'm afraid that without some type of positive development, the short sellers are going to run it into the ground. By the time we get to earnings and MWC I could be looking at some pretty substantial losses. I too feel like a chump for hanging on to a stock that the world says is trash. We've seen 8 or 9 straight days of losses. Where does it end?
That's why they pay you dividend now, so you can. Don't worry leaks about upcoming phones and tablets will start to appear soon!

it will only end if and when the board declares Tegra as what it is - Jen's hobby, without any chance of ever breaking even because the accessible TAM is way too small compared to the huge R&D program. That is, never. BTW, just curious, do you ever read the arguments presented by the negative posters here or do you just pass them by because they are just 'bashing'? Give you another hint: an R&D effort 5 yrs in the making, into the 4th generation of devices, and the loses, instead of getting smaller, is getting bigger and bigger every quarter. This thing has no chance.

Topic.Title: HOT NEWS: Nexus 7.7 specs (Tegra 4 on board) leak online; may debut at Google I/O event

Message.Msg: PC Graphics has not shrunken, o.investor. That being said, I agree that folding Tegra is NOT an option. Without it, the company has no real large growth venue other than Tesla.

It's all about growth - you either grow in new market segments or, you grow by gaining market share against competitors. At this point both avenues are questionable though there is potential. - new market segments: HPC, gaming - market share gain: smartphones, server

" this stock has to be among the worst performers" cool stuff... weak execution... products miss their target window... roadmap has shifted out a full year... "When will things change???" Project Denver... all new markets NVidia will own the high ground, the push out from there... The ARM64 era hasn't started yet...

R&D is a necessary expenditure when breaking into a new market. I agree that it has weighed on earnings, but that is expected. Out of their PC peers that have had the know-with-all to start diversifying earlier on in the cycle and that has paid off with 16% Android market share. How has AMD, Intel, Dell etc done in this space. I have no reason to believe they couldn't steal a good portion of the smartphone segment from QCOM. At this point it is only QCOM and NVIDIA left among the independents. Now, that being said it does bother me they aren't pushing their LTE technology harder...that is a point of concern and I can't tell if that is subtle hint or just logistics.

Topic.Title: HOT NEWS: Nexus 7.7 specs (Tegra 4 on board) leak online; may debut at Google I/O event

Message.Msg: I thought the Leap frog kiddie tablet was more suited for you?

Yes, R&D is a necessary expenditure but you have to question the area of investment. The market was ripe to reward a credible QCOM competitor. Instead of Icera 500 focus, Nvidia seems to have been distracted by Project Shield. Now, Nvidia is a large 7000 employee company - you would think that they will be able to chew gum and walk at the same time. But at this time, absent any market indications, I have to believe that Icera acquisition is a bust. Remember that at the time of acquisition Icera was touted as earnings accretive in 2012.
NVidia had the right strategy, right investment, just didn't execute and missed many of their opportunities. Long term... PD cores in Tegra Stark...

It's way too early to say Icera is a bust. You should know that and I think that is more emotion than rationale. R&D efforts take time and often have setbacks and thus timelines get pushed especially considering the overzealous nature of Jen. So, I am curious to what your rationale is behind it being a bust? Being a large company is not in and of itself a favorable asset and often leads to political roadblocks but I do agree they should have enough resources to right a listing ship (if that be the case). I absolutely agree that Icera should've been a bigger focus at CES and I am disappointed in the blurry timelines given and I am not sure what to make of shield at this point. I think more time is needed to let things play out. All things considered, I will agree their timeline is about 12 months behind schedule but I am not sure that it's because of shield or viability as you are suggesting. The way things are playing out (and this is why i emphasize more patience) is a bit odd. You have a company that breaks into the mobile segment does well in the tablet space, seemingly has all the tools to start stealing smartphone market share but seems to have been rather muted. Their track record at a minimum would tell me they would at least make a strong go at it before giving up.

Message.Title: NVIDIA
Message.Msg: P-I-E-C-E O-F #$%$

Brokeagain - you are too hardcore Nvidia believer. Even after 2 years, Nvidia has not been able to bring a single product from Icera to market. Mind you this in the middle of roaring mobile growth. And you question if my response if more emotion than rational? Did you know that QCOM has already investigated SDR modems and decided against that approach? There is nothing new in Icera technology - I was hoping that at least they will be quick to market but even that didn't happen. Icera had some success in USB data only modem. After Nvidia acquisition they started focusing seriously in voice support. Well that requires many protocol stacks and it has to run somewhere. SDR modems are science projects and will never beat a good ASIC solution. Thats just basic science - it was laughable when Nvidia compares LTE die-size as a differentiation.

Icera is a bust: A reasonably generous chip design cycle is about one year. Deal went through 1 year and 9 months ago, almost two whole design cycles ago. Now, they are still not registering any meaningful modem sales, either discrete or integrated, and promise is a still full design cycle off. The discrete part is the telling story. People like aapl and samsung are just dying for a second source to escape the qcom monopoly pricing. Just talk to brcm on that one. If Icera discretes are not good enough to go into any device, what makes you think they are good enough to be integrated into anything. Jen bought a lemon.

Message.Title: From Jan 4, 2013 $13+ down to now at $11+. Anyone can see this is way oversold
Message.Msg: I can feel a bounce is coming......

Although, I believe in NVIDIA, and not just for it's mobile prospects, don't get ahead of yourself and think that my belief is that of blind faith. I question your perspective only because being delayed is not in and of itself a reason to discount it's delivery to the market. I have been part of many projects that have seen significant delays but still came to fruition. I don't think the delay is enough to say it's a bust. I did not know that QCOM attempted an SDR technology however, I would caution and remind you that QCOM's core competencies DO NOT include software. Need I say anymore than the RT driver debacle. If it truly was going to be a bust I am not sure why they keep highlighting it whenever Tegra is mentioned - I would think they would move away from that. "SDR modems are science projects and will never beat a good ASIC solution. Thats just basic science - it was laughable when Nvidia compares LTE die-size as a differentiation." This is a bit myopic don't you think? As an example the same argument was used against hypervisors particularly those hardware zealots who lived and died by the metal. I could be proven wrong and that is ok but technology is meant to evolve and that is what I think will happen - hardware only solutions are becoming less and less ubiquitous.

Message.Title: "Advanced Micro Devices Inc (AMD): Today's Featured Technology Winner"
Message.Msg: "Advanced Micro Devices Inc (AMD): Today's Featured Technology Winner" "Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) pushed the Technology sector higher today making it today's featured technology winner. The sector as a whole was unchanged today. By the end of trading, Advanced Micro Devices rose 4 cents (1.5%) to $2.68 on average volume. Throughout the day, 23.6 million shares of Advanced Micro Devices exchanged hands as compared to its average daily volume of 28.2 million shares. The stock ranged in a price between $2.60-$2.70 after having opened the day at $2.62 as compared to the previous trading day's close of $2.64." source: TheStreet Wire

Topic.Title: Do you really think this market would take Apple down and Nvidia higher?

Message.Msg: "Do you really want Apple to lead tech lower?" Did you get your wish Nvidia fans? Apple was down. Did it help Nvidia? imho

ok brokeagain - I am not calling you a die-hard Nvidia homer like some others on this board. I understand the thrill of nailing the next big stock before the market has it all figured out. And Nvidia over the years has been one heck of a tease. SDR as a technology solution has been around for many years but it has never made it much beyond experimental phase. Sandbridge Tech was pursuing SDR approach (funded by Samsung) when they were scooped by Qualcomm. Most likely to restrict options for Qualcomm rather than for the technology. Icera founders are great minds - if anyone could pull out a competitive SDR solution, they were the team to do it. I don't know what has happened to that team after Nvidia acquisition. But 2 years and no new product is not a good sign. We will have to wait for MWC to see if any of this is real. Obviously CES was a disappointment from an investor point of view. By announcing Tegra 4, Nvidia has basically put the brakes on consumers looking to buy tablets with Tegra 3 - this always happens. That is why you see Apple announce products with pricing and launch dates. Unlike the stuff that Nvidia tried to pull at CES.

Message.Title: "AMD alleges former managers copied 100,000 confidential files before joining Nvidia"
Message.Msg: "AMD alleges former managers copied 100,000 confidential files before joining Nvidia" "Summary: AMD believes that a former vice-president and three managers handed trade secrets to Nvidia, after they jumped ship to join a rival hardware-making firm." "Chipmaker AMD is taking four former employees to court, one former vice-president and three former managers from the firm's Boxborough plant, who left the company to go and work for rival Nvidia last year. AMD believes that as they left the company, the four employees copied more than 100,000 confidential documents and trade secrets to take with them. The suit, filed in the U.S. District of Massachusetts, claims former vice-president Robert Feldstein, along with managers Manoo Desai, Nicolas Kociuk and Richard Hagen, took the files before the four left the company. AMD wants to recover the files, which the company claims covers everything from upcoming AMD technology and contracts with large and enterprise customers. Along with the lawsuit, the court also sanctioned a temporary restraining order against the four former employees, ordering the preservation of any copies of AMD materials they may have, any computers or devices they may own, and must not divulge or use any AMD confidential information. " Source: zdnet

Message.Msg: look, Jen gets the same treatment Michael Dell gets..all the good things you post about are disregarded by the wall st thugs. Jen needs to do the same thing. Give us shareholders a premium to today's holders and may we all succeed from there. If Jen does nothing but stay the course, then he only hurts shareholders and makes the thugs more powerful and ultimately, destroying his own company. If this buyout happens with Dell, the pressure will increase to do the same, and I will be at the forefront of the #$%$... you should too. it's over, the old days are forever gone..

I can agree with much of this. I may be a bit more positive on SDR technology but also also understand that is has limited commercial success. As for the tech savvy consumer I agree the announcement will be an impediment for purchasing a T3 powered device. I don't think it matters for devices that are less transparent to the hardware like automotive and for the consumer who just cares about the branding or product around the guts of it (the non tech savvy consumer ). One more thing - I do like the company and I feel like I understand their vision but that won't stop me from mitigating the impact owning the stock has on my portfolio. I am not emotionally attached to NVIDIA. That being said I have done well with NVIDIA, in part, because it has been beat down so much. I reduced my position a bit in order to reduce my exposure to the PC segment of NVIDIA in case Intel's earning come in below expectations. We both know what kind of impact that could have on a company like NVIDIA.

for the nth time I'll repeat myself: I don't think an integrated solution is absolutely necessary at this pt, aapl/sammie are still using discrete solutions. But it is essential to announce a package deal, one promises that the app processor WILL work with the modem/one neck to choke. We did not get that at CES. So if it won't work together separately, why would it work together on the same die??

Message.Title: Focus On The Positive
Message.Msg: 1) Nvidia became the leading independent tablet processor company in 3Q with 17% market share. Will only get better with Tegra 4 2) Tegra 4 is a killer chip...like the smartphone camera exotic stuff. Surely LG and HTC will announce phones in MWC. 3) Nvidia dominates the gamer GPU market and it's not going away. 4) No competion in Pro Graphics and Tesla is expanding rapidly. 5) Project Shield opens up a whole new way to sell chips. 6) Nvidia Grid has huge potential!! 7) Started paying a dividend in November...only up from here. and at least one other semiconductor company takes Nvidia's entry into the console gaming market very seriously...Yes AMD..just sued 4 former employees who now work for Nvidia. One was the ex ATI vice president of engineering that got AMD all those standard console contracts. Apparently he and the other 4 know too much......LOL

Message.Title: Like it or not, Nvidia is headed for the single digits. Fair value is
Message.Msg: $7. Tegra is a bust.

Topic.Title: NVIDIA has nothing to do with the alleged, illegal transfer of data by former AMD employees...

Message.Msg: My my my. My hands feel, well, unclean, merely reading about it. I'll go scrub them now.

Topic.Title: "AMD alleges former managers copied 100,000 confidential files before joining Nvidia"

Message.Msg: "AMD believes that a former vice-president and three managers handed trade secrets to Nvidia. AMD believes that as they left the company, the four employees copied more than 100,000 confidential documents and trade secrets to take with them." Hummm. And we thought last year's insider trading case was interesting, right boys?
